headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections and amplifications for April 3, 2010.

headline: What's Hot…and Not
summary: A graphical look at how different investments, from REIT shares to crude oil, fared last week.

summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: What's News: Business & Finance
summary: What's News: Business & Finance Top Stories for April 2
None

headline: Desperate Times
summary: See some key medical advances during U.S. wars and compare mortality rates.

headline: What's News: World-Wide
summary: What's News: World-Wide Top Stories for April 2

headline: Juan Williams: Tea Party Anger Reflects Mainstream Concerns
summary: Dissatisfaction with the economy and the country's direction cuts across racial lines.

headline: Rabbit, Run
summary: As Easter approaches, Long Beach City College is engaged in a massive round-up of the hundreds of bunnies that hop alongside students and devour thousands of dollars of landscaping on this campus south of Los Angeles.

headline: Mayor's Killing Is Latest Blow for Town
summary: In many ways, the shooting death Thursday of the mayor here was only the latest blow for a dilapidated village of about 5,000.

headline: New Studies Eat Into Diet Math
summary: How many calories must a dieter cut to lose a pound? New evidence suggest the mathematical formula researchers and nutritionists have long relied on underestimates the dietary changes necessary to shed unwanted weight.

headline: Militia Suspects to Stay in Jail
summary: A federal magistrate ordered eight suspected members of a Midwest Christian militia accused of conspiring to overthrow the government to remain locked up until trial.

headline: Fantasy Baseball's Toughest Tournament
summary: How a college professor and a pig farmer strike fear into the hearts of some of fantasy's top players.

headline: A Real Oracle
summary: None

headline: Vanuatu: Reminders of World War II
summary: Military wreckage can still be found on Espiritu Santo, the largest of Vanuatu's many islands and the site of the biggest U.S. base in the South Pacific during World War II. Here's a closer look at some of the vestiges of the American presence.

headline: Real Concern About Privacy of EMRs Is Not Misplaced
summary: Mary Grealy makes the fantastic assertion that electronic medical records are not more vulnerable than paper ones. Nonsense.

headline: Low Interest Rates Punish Savers and the Prudent
summary: Charles Schwab correctly highlights the problem that low interest rates create for household savers. But it's not just households' direct investment in fixed income products that's affected ("Low Interest Rates Are Squeezing Seniors," op-ed, March 30).

headline: BABs Promote Jobs and Investment
summary: Your editorial "Another Wall Street Bonus" (March 24) misconstrues the Build America Bonds (BABs) program and its effect on state and local governments.

headline: Seeing 85 Will Not Be The Blessing That Many Boomers Expect
summary: For too many baby boomers, "seeing 85" will be the worst option for living a full life ("To Double the Odds of Seeing 85: Get a Move On," Health Journal, March 9).

headline: Parent by Gut Feeling And Experience
summary: Amy Henry points out ("The Holy Grail of Parenting Wisdom," Taste, March 26) what should be, but no longer is, obvious to parents today: We don't need books to tell us how to parent.

headline: Sweatpants Go Luxe
summary: Luxury sweatpants are popping up on runways and in stores this season. The trend started with edgy designers like Isabel Marant and Alexander Wang. Recently Michael Kors introduced cashmere versions to a wider audience. Here's a look at the various ways sweatpants are being worn.

headline: Weaker Yen, Strong Economic Data Boost Asia
summary: In Japan, auto makers were among gainers after strong March sales data, while Chinese shares continued their upward trend.

headline: Week in Review
summary: View the top stories this week at OpinionJournal.com.

headline: Verizon Gets Out Ahead of Broadband Crunch
summary: Questions about whether FiOS will ever generate an adequate return have intensified. But as Internet traffic mushrooms, the Verizon Communications' investment is likely to be vindicated.

headline: New Muscle in the Mustang
summary: Ford's 2011 Mustang V6 and GT cars are powerful and fuel-efficient improvements on previous models. Here's a closer look at them.

headline: The Case for Depegging the Yuan
summary: The U.S. is enjoying some benefits from a gathering global recovery, but enough disappointment to keep the Fed from edging toward a rate hike. That could prove negative for the dollar.

headline: U.S. Asks States to DecideOn High-Risk Health-Pools
summary: The U.S. Department of Health and Human Services is asking states to decide whether they will participate in new high-risk health-insurance pools, a temporary mechanism for covering the uninsured that takes effect this summer.

headline: 'Fly Girls' Land Union-Organizing Ad
summary: An AFL-CIO affiliate plans to kick off a Virgin America union-organizing campaign during the debut of the reality-TV show "Fly Girls," which features the airline.

headline: Actor Malkovich Wants More From Madoff
summary: A trust associated with actor John Malkovich challenged the amount it can recover from the liquidation of convicted Ponzi-scheme operator Bernard Madoff's firm, seeking $2.23 million instead of $670,000.

headline: Inspector General Slams Mortgage Plan
summary: A government watchdog agency criticized the Obama administration's $50 billion campaign to avert foreclosures by reducing mortgage payments for millions of distressed borrowers.

headline: Jobs Data Lift Stock Futures, Dollar; Treasurys Fall
summary: Treasury prices fell sharply, while stock futures and the dollar edged higher after data showed U.S. employers created jobs at the fastest pace in three years in March.

headline: Creditors Should Call Time on MGM
summary: There may be only one way the lenders to Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc. can avoid taking a bath on their investment in the leveraged buyout: Get in a hot-tub time machine and return to 2004 to undo the deal.

headline: Jobless Recovery? That Didn't Last Long
summary: All in all, the jobs report suggests the much-feared "jobless recovery" was short-lived. But--and in this economic cycle there have been frequent "buts"--challenges remain. The ranks of long-term unemployed increased further, and wages remain weak.

headline: Spring Break for Job Market
summary: If the labor market had a theme tune, it would be Queen's "I Want to Break Free." There were    encouraging signs of stabilization in March. The problem is that there is so much ground to make up.

headline: Israeli Air Strikes Hit Gaza Strip
summary: Israeli warplanes struck the Hamas-controlled Gaza Strip, destroying what the military said were weapons-related targets a day after a Gaza-fired rocket landed in Israel.

headline: Sell to Renter or Short Sale?
summary: Underwater on the mortgage to their second home, a California couple debates a short sale, possibly to the home's current renter. June Fletcher offers tips.

headline: Guinea Bissau Premier Released
summary: A top military officer in Guinea-Bissau claimed to have seized control of the nation's army and the prime minister was briefly detained, triggering fears of another coup in crisis-struck West Africa.

headline: Weaker Yen, Strong Economic Data Boost Asia
summary: Tokyo rose 0.4% as auto makers benefits from strong sales data, while bullishness in China shares continued following strong economic data.

headline: Credit-Crunch Relic Gets Fresh Look
summary: The first signs of life are appearing in the comatose market for securities made up of mortgages that don't carry government backing. But don't call it a revival.

headline: Stocks Gain on Manufacturing News
summary: Stocks began the second quarter on a high note, helped by new data showing that the economies of the U.S., Europe, and China are improving.

headline: U.S. Firms Criticize Chinese Rules
summary: American companies doing business in China say they are increasingly running up against discriminatory government policies.

headline: GM Daewoo Narrows Loss
summary: GM Daewoo, the South Korean unit of General Motors, benefited from an improving economy.

headline: Japan's Kan Plans Trillion-Yen Stimulus
summary: Japan's finance minister said Friday he plans to spend a one-trillion-yen ($10.67 billion) emergency reserve in this fiscal year's national budget to galvanize the country's economy.

headline: J.P. Morgan in Deal With LNG Firm
summary: J.P. Morgan Chase is pushing deeper into the energy industry through a deal with a liquefied-natural-gas importer.

headline: Hong Kong Wants Hontex to Repay IPO Funds
summary: Hong Kong's securities regulator is seeking court approval to recover nearly $130 million raised by a Chinese clothing maker accused of providing investors with false or misleading information.

headline: Job Market Picks Up, but Slowly
summary: U.S. employers added 162,000 jobs in March, the largest gain since 2007. But nearly one-third came from temporary hiring for the Census. The unemployment rate was steady at 9.7%.

headline: Changes to Muni Ratings Could Puzzle Fund Investors
summary: Two major credit-rating services are set to tweak their systems for rating U.S. municipal bonds this month, and the results could prove confusing for some mutual-fund investors.

headline: Scholastic Loss Narrows on Cost Cuts
summary: Scholastic posted a narrower loss on lower expenses while the publisher's revenue dropped on strong prior-year sales from the "Harry Potter" series.

headline: Stocks Extend Win Streak to Five Weeks
summary: U.S. stocks climbed broadly as better-than-expected data on jobs and manufacturing lifted a broad swath of stocks, including Walt Disney and Alcoa.

headline: Leah Ward Sears: How About Those Tomato Sandwiches...
summary: What does a former chief justice of the Georgia Supreme Court do when she's mistaken for the restroom attendant?

headline: Best-Selling BooksWeek Ended March 28
summary: With data from Nielsen BookScan

headline: Real (and Fake) Hoofbeats of the Pony Express
summary: A business that lasted 18 months in real life has survived 150 years in myth.

headline: Sour Notes at a Sinatra Show
summary: Unions are battling over whether Twyla Tharp's "Come Fly Away" is a musical play or an evening of dance.

headline: Not So Smart RIM
summary: Research In Motion is making hay in the lower-end of the smartphone market. That isn't a good long-term growth strategy.

headline: Factories Revive Economy
summary: The manufacturing sector geared up production across the globe in March, fueling optimism that the economic recovery has legs.

headline: Catholics Retool Rosary
summary: As modern-day Catholics discover the rosary anew they are also updating the instrument and creating a market for nontraditional interpretations.

headline: Citigroup's Primerica IPO Soars 31%
summary: Citigroup's insurance arm Primerica surged 31% in its trading debut. Citigroup sold 21.4 million shares in the IPO, 3.4 million more than originally planned.

headline: U.S. Revamps Air-Passenger Screening
summary: The U.S. and other nations will roll out a new air-security system that will gather various pieces of information and flag people for increased scrutiny even if their names aren't on a terrorist watch list.

headline: In the Time of Jane Austen
summary: Cynthia Crossen on why Jane Austen is more well known than popular contemporaries like Fanny Burney, Elizabeth Gaskell and Maria Edgeworth.

headline: Noonan: The Catholic Church's Catastrophe
summary: The press and the pope deserve credit for confronting scandal.

headline: Karzai Rails Against West
summary: Afghan President Karzai accused "foreign embassies" of trying to bribe members of the Afghan election commission, and claimed the U.N. mission chief threatened to kill one official.

headline: Church Officials Assail Abuse, Defend Pontiff
summary: Pope Benedict XVI delivered a somber Good Friday address that emphasized rebirth and conversion but didn't address the allegations of sexual abuse that have roiled the Roman Catholic church.

headline: Money Fund Assets Under $3 Trillion by ICI Count
summary: None

headline: TSMC Has No Plans to Move Plants
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing's CEO says sales to China could overtake those to Japan this year, but he has no plans to move his most advanced manufacturing plants any closer to his Chinese customers.

headline: EPA Toughens Mining Permits
summary: The EPA tightened water-quality standards that could severely limit surface coal-mining operations in Appalachia. Mining-industry officials said the change was unfair.

headline: WellPoint Unit Drops Stellaris
summary: A unit of WellPoint dropped Stellaris, a four-hospital chain in Westchester, N.Y., from its network after Stellaris asked for a 15% increase in reimbursement payments from the health insurer.

headline: State, Local Tax Revenue Rises
summary: State and local tax collections in the U.S. rose above year-earlier levels in the fourth quarter for the first time in more than a year.

headline: Taliban Silence Kandahar's Clerics
summary: The Taliban have silenced the pro-government religious authorities of Kandahar through assassination and intimidation, giving the insurgents control of much of a city that the U.S. will attempt to secure.

headline: No Open Road for a Gasoline Rally
summary: With demand down, gasoline prices might not take their typical summer spike.

headline: Administration Sets Car-Mileage Rules
summary: The White House finalized rules designed to cut gasoline consumption and greenhouse-gas emissions. But despite publicity about electric cars, auto makers for the next few years will rely on more mundane solutions.

headline: Benmosche Upbeat on AIG Prospects
summary: AIG's CEO said it has made significant progress in asset sales, in reducing risk exposures at its derivatives unit, and dealing with bonus payments. Also, the Treasury selected two new board members to be appointed directors of AIG.

headline: Ford Press Secretary Made News
summary: Jerald terHorst was President Ford's first press secretary, and made news himself when he resigned in the wake of the president's pardon of President Nixon.

headline: Mortgage Risk Premiums Widen
summary: Mortgage-backed securities stumbled as the market struggled to adjust to the absence of Federal Reserve buying.

headline: Hedge Fund M&A Faces Hurdles
summary: Hedge-fund consolidation historically has been a case of much talk, little action. Anticipation is running high that 2010 will be different. But expectations of a deal glut could again prove wide of the mark.

headline: Green Day's Great White Way
summary: With the rock opera "American Idiot" opening, pop-punk star Billie Joe Armstrong confesses show-tune secrets.

headline: IPad Lands Role in 'Modern Family'
summary: The iPad tablet computer was a pivotal part of the plot in the sitcom 'Modern Family' on Wednesday night, but Apple says it didn't pay for product placement.

headline: Crash of 'The Titans'
summary: Shoddy 3-D flattens the Greek gods and heroes of "Clash of the Titans," but illuminated animators were behind "The Secret of Kells," writes Joe Morgenstern.

headline: Building Your Own Antique
summary: How Waterworks's co-founders, Barbara and Robert Sallick, re-created an 18th-century home in Connecticut.

headline: Greek Interest Cost: Not a Tragedy
summary: Greece's borrrowing costs are high, but not too high for it to handle. The critical issue is whether the government can keep reducing its budget deficit.

headline: Weekends With the War Channel
summary: With Saturday programming like this on television, justto walk away from the screen, writes Dorothy Rabinowitz.

headline: Strassel: Michael Steele's Job
summary: Why the Republican Party chairman's spending is now an issue.

headline: Burkle Presses Barnes & Noble
summary: Activist investor Ronald Burkle has asked Barnes & Noble to add three to four new, independent directors to the bookseller's nine-member board.

headline: Morgan Stanley New CEO Earned $15 Million in 2009
summary: James Gorman earned the money as Morgan Stanley co-president in 2009. The top five executives gathered total bonuses of $25 million, excluding stock awards.

headline: China Visit Suggests Thaw Over Iran
summary: China announced that President Hu Jintao will visit the U.S. to discuss nuclear security, pointing to a potential thaw in one of the worst stretches of U.S.-China relations in recent memory.

headline: Quicksilver, Borders Lead Small-Cap Rally
summary: Consumer-discretionary and staple sectors posted healthy gains as U.S. small-capitalization stocks climbed on the first day of the second quarter.

headline: Unemployed Cloud the Jobs Picture
summary: The payrolls report Friday is expected to show some job creation. But any cheering will be tempered by concern over the number of long-term unemployed, Gerald Seib writes.

headline: Military Takeover Points to Guinea-Bissau
summary: A top military officer in Guinea-Bissau claimed to have seized control of the nation's army and the prime minister was briefly detained, triggering fears of another coup in crisis-struck West Africa.

headline: Merger Deals in Asia Notch Record Growth
summary: Asian merger activity grew at a record pace in the first quarter, as bankers scrambled to help foreign firms tap the region's growing markets, and to fund local companies' expansion abroad.

headline: Amazon's Opening With iPad
summary: With the iPad, Apple won't have its usual leg up for selling e-books, like it does with content for the iPod or iPhone, giving Amazon a chance to be a major e-book provider for the device.

headline: Swiss-Knifed
summary: None

headline: 'Perfect' Oil Price Slipping Away
summary: Oil smashed through recent highs to trade near $85 a barrel just after the world's biggest oil producers and consumers agreed that months of stable prices had benefited a fragile world economy.

headline: Gathering for Gardner
summary: Homage to the iconic author of Scientific American's "Mathematical Games" column.

headline: Jay Rockefeller and Olympia Snowe: Now Is the Time to Prepare for Cyberwar
summary: Hackers can already steal from our networks. They could paralyze them too.

headline: Baseball Gets Defensive
summary: With the 2010 MLB season set to begin, some of the sport's most innovative franchises have decided to rebuild their lineups by investing in fielders. But does nifty glovework sell tickets?

headline: A Defense of Drones
summary: The Obama Administration justifies targeted killing in the war on terror.

headline: U.S. Sues KBR on Costs
summary: A Justice Department suit accuses one of the U.S. military's largest contractors of improperly charging taxpayers for the cost of private security guards in Iraq. KBR disputed the claims.

headline: Oregon Pear Growers Sour on Law
summary: Oregon farmers say a landmark 1970s measure aimed at conserving agricultural areas has limited their ability to raise cash, putting some farms out of business.

headline: Daniel Ikenson: China Trade and American Jobs
summary: Studies suggest that one-half to two-thirds of the value of 'Chinese' imports is added in other countries, including the U.S.

headline: Verizon, Exelon to Record Charge
summary: The companies are the latest to take charges to account for the impact of the U.S. health-care overhaul.

headline: Peter Wolf: A Rock and Roll Dinosaur Rolls On
summary: From the J. Geils Band to an overlooked solo career, Peter Wolf is keeping it all old-school.

headline: Idled Workers Find 'Furlough Friday' Deals
summary: Businesses are courting state employees forced to take time off, offering discounts on items ranging from ski lift tickets to sushi.

headline: Armstrong Risks Rainy Cobbled Roads
summary: Cyclist Lance Armstrong will face other riders in the Tour of Flanders, but his biggest opponents may be the wet cobblestones along the route. Elsewhere, the Reds are considering some, um, green additions to the rotation.

headline: U.S. Holds Pirates After Standoff
summary: Somali pirates fired at a U.S. Navy warship on Thursday, in one of the more brazen attacks of armed men in skiffs who prey upon vessels plying the sea lanes of the Indian Ocean.

headline: Comparing Apples and Oranges
summary: Homes with orchards in Connecticut, California and Washington.

headline: Hong Kong to Ease Incorporation Process
summary: Hong Kong wants to make it faster and easier to set up a corporation, even as recent U.S. criminal cases have revealed some tax evaders use Hong Kong shell companies to hide their identities.

headline: Finding People to Answer Your Questions
summary: Aardvark is a service that connects people who have questions with people who might answer them.

headline: Crude Climbs to 17-Month High
summary: Crude futures ended at a 17-month high, as rising gasoline inventories failed to stop the oil market's latest surge.

headline: The First Taste of 2009
summary: Sampling the first wines of the new Bordeaux vintage en primeur. The good news: The wines are great.

headline: Toyota Sales Rise 51% in Japan
summary: Toyota Motor's sales in Japan rose 51% in March from a year earlier, highlighting the strength of the brand in its home market despite a series of global safety recalls.

headline: Germany Probes UBS Claims
summary: The German financial regulator BaFin has launched a special probe into allegations of tax evasion at the German branch of Swiss bank UBS.

headline: Merrill Wins in Auction-Rate Case
summary: A federal judge has dismissed a lawsuit against Merrill Lynch by investors in auction-rate securities who claimed that the securities firm manipulated the market.

headline: Stephanopoulos Sells in Georgetown
summary: George Stephanopoulos's home in Georgetown has sold for $5.45 million. Plus, football's Randall Cunningham agrees to sell a Las Vegas house, and the price of a ranch property in Aspen, Colo., is cut by 33%.

headline: Richemont to Buy Net-a-Porter
summary: Swiss luxury goods maker Richemont announced a deal to buy U.K.-based online retailer Net-a-Porter, signaling the increasing importance high-end consumer goods companies are assigning to online sales.

headline: Treasury to Sell $165 Billion
summary: The Treasury on Thursday announced plans to sell $165 billion next week in short-term and long-term securities.

headline: Prescription-Drug Sales Rise 5.1%
summary: IMS Health said U.S. prescription-drug sales rose 5.1% in 2009.

headline: Storage Data Rallies Natural Gas
summary: Natural-gas futures ended nearly 6% higher on data showing a smaller-than-expected build in natural-gas inventories last week.

headline: I've Been to a Marvelous 'Party'
summary: For the first time in four decades, the play that won T.S. Eliot a Tony Award, "The Cocktail Party," is back in New York. Terry Teachout reviews.

headline: Andrew J. Coulson: Escalante Stood and Delivered. It's Our Turn.
summary: The teachers union opposed his effort to expand his class beyond 35 students.

headline: March Car Sales Climb 24% in U.S.
summary: U.S. auto sales surged in March to more than one million cars and light trucks, helped by a strengthening economy and buyer incentives from most car makers.

headline: Datebook | April 2-8
summary: Producer Jerry Bruckheimer's new drama "Miami Medical"; ...David Byrne's "Here Lies Love;" ...and more.

headline: Insurers, Regulators Fight on Premiums
summary: As insurers wrestle with the changes coming from the health overhaul, they also face challenges at the state level from regulators seeking to head off premium hikes. A court case in Maine underscores the tensions.

headline: Why So-So Payrolls Report Is a Winner
summary: A softer-than-expected employment report could keep the Fed at bay, which would be of benefit to stock investors.

headline: John Steele Gordon: As Peaceful as a Tea Party
summary: The only person arrested in recent days for threatening violence against a politician targeted Eric Cantor, the No. 2 Republican in the House.

headline: U.S. Ex-Officials Meet With Hamas
summary: Several high-profile former U.S. officials, some with close ties to the Obama administration, met with leaders of Hamas in recent months.

headline: Boola Moolah! Food Fight at Yale
summary: On the front lines at the corporate naming-rights game.

headline: Options Traders Go Bullish on Tech
summary: Options traders demonstrated confidence in Qualcomm, Micron Technology and Red Hat, selling "put" options in all three technology companies in hopes the stocks stay strong in coming weeks.

headline: Behind the Set
summary: Hiring a design company that has built stage sets for the Met, Sigur Rós singer Jónsi takes a theatrical approach to his upcoming solo tour.

headline: ObamaCare and the Constitution
summary: If Congress can force you to buy insurance, Article I limits on federal power are a dead letter.

headline: Secrets of a Good Samaritan
summary: Canadian novelist Marina Endicott probes her protagonist's act of selflessness.

headline: Animal Advocates Step Up Tactics
summary: Animal-rights groups are cleverly using little-invoked state laws in an approach that is picking up steam nationally.

headline: You Want Parity? Don't Go to Scotland
summary: In the world of sports, what leagues have the biggest discrepancy between the rich and the poor? Hint: It's not the Yankees.

headline: EU to Probe Chinese Subsidies
summary: The EU will soon begin an investigation into subsidies that the China allegedly gives to a domestic industry, which could lead to a host of new tariffs against Chinese exporters.

headline: New Curbs for TARP-Recipient First Banks
summary: First Banks was put under tough new restrictions by U.S. regulators, raising questions about the government's ability to recover the $295.4 million in capital it invested in the firm.

headline: Generic Sanofi Drugs Are Delayed
summary: Sanofi-Aventis said it settled a U.S. patent lawsuit with four generic-drug makers over their versions of its cancer treatment Eloxatin.

headline: Survival Odds Rise Sharply for Soldiers
summary: Every war brings medical innovations, as surgeons are forced to come up with new ways to save lives. But the rising survival rate is in turn introducing new problems caring for patients with chronic injuries.

headline: Best of the Web Today: Hurry Up and Wait
summary: In his latest show of chutzpah, Obama asks for patience with the law he rammed through.
